text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: if we can just contain it. Now, sometimes people just take it twice a day, kind of like before bed for sure so you sleep well Patient: Right. Doctor: and then when you’re kind of up and running whether it’s after breakfast and you’re like I’m gonna get as much stuff as I can done and I’m just gonna relax and wait for my next dose. Some of my guys have to take it three times a day and some of my guys are just like I’m okay, I can stand this stuff, it’s doable but at night I just can’t sleep. text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Here I’m happy to say the product is definitely of high grade. Uh, but you’ve got to give it two days out of every week. Okay? So logistically that means as long as they are given twenty-four hours apart, you can just come up once, and the study pays for you to stay overnight at a hotel. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? But that’s weekly. Patient: Okay, well I - Doctor: So like you’ll come up. You’ll get the one day where you get the chemo and the vitamin C. The next day 24 hours later you get vitamin C and you can go home. Patient: Oh well- Doctor: And the same next week, same thing. So you always stay overnight at a hotel. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But they’ll cover that cost. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah.

text: Family Member: He thought it was better for the body. Doctor: Yeah, it’s not as a home run, you know, there’s nothing that tells me we should do it off road to do that at this moment. Patient: Yeah, okay. Doctor: That’s probably the best way to say it. Nothing that says oh, man, this abstract tells me this is like a home run. No, I think it just adds more side effects. Patient: Yeah, okay, good, okay Doctor: Yeah, so, I know prostate cancer is the one cancer we can’t seem to plot. We love combining stuff. Patient: Right. Doctor: We’re all like crazy mad scientists in the back. Go, here’s what I, look, that’s what we like to do but with prostate cancer every time we do that it doesn’t behave. It either does nothing but give you more side effects or it just causes a problem. You know, like if you combine this with Zytiga you get more fractures. That’s no good. Patient: Right, I remember you saying that at one of our visits you were saying that. Doctor: Yeah and so just because theoretically like well, they should kind of work together. Patient: Right, Right. Doctor: It just doesn’t so we learned most of the drugs in prostate cancer it’s not like the other cancers where you do two or three drugs together. You know, we’re kind of like the loner group so it’s one at a time, sequence matters with one. Family Member: So this other doctor is going to explain the side effects he may get from radiation?

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Because you have to be positive to go onto that study. The other two studies, it doesn’t matter about what your AR-V7. AR-V7 gives us a sense of what’s the likelihood that Enzalutamide’s gonna work. Patient: Okay. Doctor: What’s the likelihood that Abiraterone’s gonna work. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Um. In this case, we’re trying to just sort out men who, um, have an AR-V7 positive as a bad thing. Uh. So, that says that we’re willing to go with immune therapy which hasn’t been proven at a high risk/high gain, uh, thing in that kind of individual. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh. (pause) Patient: Right. Doctor: That it’s clear that this isn’t helping you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, we could say, “No, let’s move on.” I can give you the, uh, consent forms. But, if you already know, that I don’t want to do chemotherapy, I know I’m not going to come in here. The consent form does explain chemotherapy. So, that’s something that you’d be entertaining as a next step, whether it be here or locally.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
